s.text: The life's work matters less than the lifestyle.
The life's work matters less than the lifestyle.
Maybe the best way to portray a character like Clare Boothe Luce would be to transport her to fiction.
But after six long years of marriage and one child, he wasn't yet in "dying condition," Clare complained, "and I am not going to waste my life waiting for him to get in it."
She took a seat at an empty desk in the editorial department and waited for some work to arrive.
But though she turned out a couple of plays after that, they never achieved the same kind of critical or commercial success.
But though she turned out a couple of plays after that, they never achieved the same kind of critical or commercial success.
In the early 1930s, she served briefly as the managing editor of Vanity Fair , then a deco dream of a magazine gleaming with smart chat.
In the early 1930s, she served briefly as the managing editor of Vanity Fair , then a deco dream of a magazine gleaming with smart chat.
In the early 1930s, she served briefly as the managing editor of Vanity Fair , then a deco dream of a magazine gleaming with smart chat.

Her parents were poor, and her mother, Ann Snyder, obsessed with trading first on her own beauty and then on Clare's for a life of satin sheets and annual sailings on the Conte di Savoia . Neither was especially nice about it.
In a way Luce is the ideal subject for this particular moment in the art of biography.

What made her famous is that she did all these things in one lifetime, like a paper doll that comes with different costumes for different vocations (the girl about town, the war correspondent, the ambassador); that she did them all and was beautiful; that she did them all in a perfumed cloud of scandal and glamour, trailed by many lovers and by gossip that she herself stoked with her acerbic tongue and her thirst for celebrity.
But after six long years of marriage and one child, he wasn't yet in "dying condition," Clare complained, "and I am not going to waste my life waiting for him to get in it."
But after six long years of marriage and one child, he wasn't yet in "dying condition," Clare complained, "and I am not going to waste my life waiting for him to get in it."
But we have no Edith Wharton, and this is the age of Real Lives.

But none of that prevented Ann from rejecting a New York hotel because it was "a dirty place full of Jews" (as Clare later put it), or from explaining to Clare that she could never marry Jacobs because "I don't want my children to have a Jewish father."
Luce's fame was a floaty, ineffable thing, not easy to get at with "yes" or "no" inquiries.
